article_title: Vichier-Guerre: Texas' health-care system: separate and unequal
article_text:
Vichier-Guerre: Texas' health-care system: separate and unequal

Photo: Charles Kelly, STF More than 50 years after Martin Luther King Jr.'s﻿ "I Have a...

In 1963, Martin Luther King Jr. called America to rise from the "dark and desolate valley of segregation." Over half a century after his most famous speech, Texas is creating a new kind of segregation and pushing us farther from King's dream. With the majority of uninsured Texans being people of color, Texas' refusal to provide access to health care for our state's poorest adults is worsening racial health inequalities. Texas legislators are choosing to keep our health care system separate and unequal.

article_metadata.description: With the majority of uninsured Texans being people of color, Texas' refusal to provide access to health care for our state's poorest adults is worsening racial health inequalities.  With passage of the Affordable Care Act in 2010, Medicaid eligibility was supposed to expand in all states to help more Americans near and below the poverty level access needed medical care.  In 2012, a Supreme Court ruling upheld the law but allowed states to opt out of the Medicaid expansion provision.  [...] a new Mason-Dixon Line has been forming in our health care system, with most Midwestern and Southern states choosing not to expand Medicaid.  [...] 3 in 4 uninsured Texans are people of color.
article_metadata.author.name: By Cecilia Vichier-Guerre
